firstStepsPage.title: First-time setup in 4 steps
firstStepsPage.lead: Skip theory for now and run the workflow once. These four steps are enough to start.

1.title: 1) Create your learning profile
1.description: On first launch, create a profile. Data is isolated per profile, so multiple learners can share one device.

2.title: 2) Create one card pack
2.description: Organize by topic, like "Interview Q&A" or "Medical terms". One topic per pack keeps reviews focused.

3.title: 3) Add 10-20 core cards
3.description: Do not start too big. Add the highest-value items you need soon so you can see results quickly.

4.title: 4) Finish your first review today
4.description: Recall first, reveal answer second, then grade honestly. The app schedules the next review automatically.

checklist.1: Keep cards short: one idea per card.
checklist.2: Write specific prompts, not vague ones.
checklist.3: Prioritize active recall over passive familiarity.
checklist.4: Use a fixed daily review window.

workflowPage.title: How this product helps you remember
workflowPage.lead: The core is not rereading often. It is recalling at the moment you are close to forgetting.

1.title: Create cards
1.description: Break knowledge into small units that can be asked and answered.

2.title: Recall actively
2.description: See the prompt first and try to answer before revealing.

3.title: Check and grade
3.description: Compare with the correct answer and grade your current mastery.

4.title: Auto scheduling
4.description: Better recall extends intervals; weak recall shortens them.

5.title: Repeat loop
5.description: You only handle due cards each day, which keeps study time controlled.

workflowPage.tip: Practical order: clear due cards first, then add new learning. This keeps pressure stable.

memoryCurvePage.title: Advanced: memory curve and spaced review
memoryCurvePage.lead: The forgetting curve shows fast loss in the first days, then a slower decline. The goal is to review when memory is weak but not gone.

1.title: Why spacing matters
1.description: Cramming feels easy now but fades quickly. Spaced recall is harder, and that effort builds stronger memory.

2.title: How grades change intervals
2.description: If recall is easy, the next review moves later. If recall is weak, the next review comes sooner.

3.title: Your one job
3.description: Grade honestly. Inflated grades break scheduling quality.

intervals.1: After first successful recall: same day or next day
intervals.2: After second successful recall: in 2-3 days
intervals.3: After third successful recall: around 1 week
intervals.5: Long-term stage: adapt based on forgetting signals

1.question: How do I share a card pack?
1.answer: Use Export to generate a JSON file and send it. The other person imports it into their own profile.

2.question: Why do I still forget after I feel confident?
2.answer: That is normal. Short-term familiarity is not long-term retention. Follow due reviews instead of reviewing only when you remember.

3.question: How long should I review each day?
3.answer: Start with 15-25 minutes daily. Keep it consistent for two weeks before increasing new cards.

4.question: Quick Review vs Normal Review?
4.answer: Quick Review does not update scheduling. Normal Review updates intervals from your grades, so use it as your default.

5.question: How many cards should one pack contain?
5.answer: For beginners, start around 30-80 cards per pack. Split the pack if the topic becomes too broad.
